chunks.en: Taobao's Spring Festival non-stop service is a joke.
My deliveries from late January and early February haven't arrived after six or seven days.
STO, Yunda, YTO, and ZTO have already stopped operating early.
Cainiao will also stop operating after tomorrow, and I don't even know where the delivery guys will leave the packages even if they deliver them.
In conclusion, it's going to be over sooner or later.
From my observation, JD delivery guys are still busy every day, with no changes, and next-day delivery is very punctual.
Courier: Taobao's non-stop Spring Festival service has nothing to do with me. ğŸ¤”ï¸
Could it be that... JD is for buying delivery speed (JD is a delivery company), and TB is for buying a wide variety of goods...?

chunks.en: For common, standardized items, you can buy them on JD and get them the next day. If there's no next-day delivery, who would spend more money on JD? But for non-standardized, common items, JD also has many third-party sellers, and using non-JDL doesn't make it any faster, it's about the same as TB, and generally slightly more expensive.
TB is for finding basically anything you want, and if you can't find it there, you have to go to Xiaohuangyu. As for the delivery time, are you kidding me with 'wanting both'?
Shouldn't this be common knowledge?
Non-stop my ass!
I bought something on the 31st, and it hasn't arrived today.
All orders placed in February show that they will be shipped before February 19th.
I immediately went to JD to buy it again, and it arrived the next day.
@showgood163 I wouldn't ask how many days it will take to arrive; that's a stupid question. The seller can't possibly know how many days it will take.

But I've learned my lesson this year, and now I know how to play it. You don't need to ask how many days it will take to arrive, you just need to confirm whether he really shipped it. If you want to be safe, you can also ask if he knows whether the online store that receives his delivery actually has someone sending it out, which he can know. If he can't explain it clearly, then I won't take the risk.

That's what happened with my previous order. The situation was that the receiving station simply had no one to send it to the transfer center. As long as someone sends it to the transfer center, the rest is fine. The remaining thing is that you need to confirm which delivery company the other party uses and when the delivery company stopped sending around your area.
The other things I bought these days were even faster than usual because I'm in Guangdong, and there shouldn't be any traffic towards Guangdong on the highway. I'm not sure about other places.
@showgood163 #7 Go to JD, next-day delivery.
Same with PDD, I ended up choosing to order from JD.
This non-stop thing is killing merchants. We have to be open until 1 AM, what a stupid thing, and we can't even withdraw from registration.
Shipping as usual, but the couriers aren't moving at all. The non-stop service has no real effect and only tortures the merchants.
@docx I agree. If the goods can't be received, it's better not to bother the merchants and customers.
@sickoo Is it that bad?
What's the point? Even if you place an order and it's shipped, it won't arrive until after the Spring Festival.
I contacted the courier company to complain, and it felt like the courier company didn't care at all. As the recipient, there's nothing I can do about it.
When the merchants ask, they say that delivery time cannot be guaranteed during the Spring Festival.
I was originally going to find a store that was open during the Spring Festival to buy something, but after reading the above comments, I'll wait.

Last year, I went home for the Spring Festival and found that the router was broken. I hurriedly placed an order on JD on the first day of the Lunar New Year, and it was delivered to me on the second day.
After the prosperity fades, only a mess remains.
Does anyone remember how many days before the Spring Festival the logistics started to slow down in previous years?
I also bought five or six items on the 31st (December 21st of the Lunar calendar), and they only arrived today.
I thought it would only slow down a few days before New Year's Eve.
When it matters, you still have to rely on JD...

@evan9527 Merchants who are labeled as open during the Spring Festival state that they will ship within 24 or 48 hours. The remaining merchants will ship before February 19th. However, merchants shipping on time does not mean deliveries will arrive on time.
Taobao probably just doesn't want the platform's transaction volume to decrease too much this month. Even if the experience is a little worse, it's just a little worse.

I searched and found that this event has been around since 2022. I can only say that they were dominant at the time, and everyone had no choice but to endure it. Now they still dare to do this, are they afraid of not dying fast enough?

@wushan I also think that the delivery service this year is not as good as in previous years. I remember that in previous years, I could normally receive deliveries from STO, Yunda, YTO, and ZTO five days before the Spring Festival.
Did the pandemic knock them off?

A victim reporting. This year's non-stop service is the worst shopping experience I've ever had. I placed an order around January 27th or 28th, and the delivery hasn't moved since the courier picked it up. I don't know if it's the courier or the merchant who are playing tricks. If there are no accidents, it would be the courier. It is less likely the merchant, because I asked the merchant a question before buying that day. If they did this and received a bad review it would be much worse for them.
In the past, if they were selling, they sold. If they weren't selling, they weren't selling. It was clean and simple.
However, let me say a word for the platform, everything is difficult at the beginning, the first year made mistakes but it should be better in the future.
@showgood163 Just ask clearly if they will ship before buying. There are still many that really ship. My later purchases are not problems. Only the one I bought at the end of January was a problem.
@testonly I searched on Bilibili, and this event should have started in 2022, so this is the third year.

@euph #16 Maybe it didn't start this year, but this year is clearly different from previous years. I also bought a bunch of stuff at the end of last year, but most sellers clearly stated on the page when they would be on vacation, but many didn't write this year.

The thing I bought at the end of last month, if they hadn't done this, I wouldn't have missed it at all. At that time, there were many that were shipping normally. By the time I realized it wasn't moving, almost everyone selling that thing had stopped working, someone on Pinduoduo was still selling it, but it was much more expensive, killed by that courier.

In fact, if you call the seller and ask about products that are still being sold today, and they say they will still ship the parcel, then that most likely means that they have confirmed that their partner courier is still working. The main point to consider is if the courier in your location is still delivering. It seems that the Cainiao delivery station in my area has someone on duty during this time, so you should always ask the seller which courier company they use.
